dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: North Hayworth Avenue, off Sunset Boulevard. A quiet, tre lined residential street. Note the small apartment comple set back from the curb.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTION
dialogues.text: Our narrator is HENRY OBERT (O-BURT)(30).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where where F. Scott Fitzgerald died on December 21, 1940. INSERT ARCHIVAL PHOTOS of Fitzgerald.   His work.   His l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fitzgerald was one of the truly great American writers of the 20th century. Tender is the Night. The Last Tycoon. This Side of Paradise. And, of course, my favorite, The Great Gatsby. But Fitzgerald ended up out here. Writing movies that never got made. Drinking too much. Alienating people. Losing his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry stands on the sidewalk. Full of promise and hope. Wears a pizza delivery outfit as he stares at the apartme more with reverence than curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stop by here sometimes--out of respect. Fitzgerald had this amazing gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry crosses the street--heading for his parked Honda. unlocks the car. Swings open the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he wasted it. He wasted his talent. Henry yanks a MAGNETIC SIGN out of the back seat and slap it on the outside of the driver's door: PIZZA STARZ. One last glance at the fabled apartment complex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I sell my novel, I won't make his mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man (40's) and woman (30's) sit on the couch in their tastefully-decorated San Fernando Valley home. Expensive taste in clothes. Her cleavage a bit too obvious. Both seem a little uncomfortable. Uncertain. CAPTION: DR. ALAN & COLETTE MOONEY They look off to the side, speaking to someone off-camera

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We thought this was going to be a reality series.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, like the Kardashians. They listen.    Here comes the bad news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Really? A documentary? This is going to be a documentary about our writing group?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole group. Not just us, right? Not that it should be just about us... Nervous laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They look at each other: A documentary? They try to mask their disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this is going to be like--like what I saw the other night on cable? About bees mating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or that, um, that one about the Holocaust. Colette nods, remembering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty...Pretty--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Powerful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powerful.   Yes. Powerful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We love documentaries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do. They look at each other again: What have we gotten into?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natasha, the Russian peasant, dressed oh-so-slowly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A POSTER BOARD SIGN--someone went to Kinko's--is posted prominently reading: QUIET, PLEASE--WRITERS AT WORK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...consumed totally, completely, absolutely, by endless thoughts of Yuri fondling her breast, his other hand groping her womanhood, knowing... They sit around the dining room table. Colette, convinced she's the next Amy Tan, reads aloud from her TYPED PAGES. The others all have copies in front of them. We recognize Henry, the frog waiting to become a prince, making copiou notes and Alan, oh-so-proud, hanging on every word. Beami Three others round out the group: Younger MAN (early 30s). Unshaven. Always thinks he's the coolest guy in any room. Can't avoid glances at the camer

dialogues.speaker: CAPTION
dialogues.text: The OLDEST MEMBER of the group (over 60) sits with his ar folded as he listens, shifting in his chair. Captain Grum

dialogues.speaker: CAPTION
dialogues.text: Finally, the young (mid-to-late 20s), angelic, WOMAN list intently, the one who probably stopped to rescue a cat on her way here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Any second that she might explode, her chastity spraying across the ceiling...Spraying across the ceiling like passionate graffiti. Natasha never thought such a moment possible. "Have I satisfied you, Natasha?" Yuri had inquired after their fourth round of vodka-soaked lovemaking. "Nyet, Not yet," Natasha stated, exhausted, but grateful. Awkward silence around the table as Colette removes her reading glasses and waits. Alan clears his throat, lookin cheerful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?   Comments?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry's sparse studio apartment. Minimal furniture. His l is set up on an old door, stretched across some blue plas crates. There are BOOKS piled everywhere. All sorts of books. And PAPER -- pieces of paper, including letters and cards and printed emails, dozens of them, are taped throughout the small apartment. We are introduced to Henry the writer: pondering over his battered laptop, pacing up and down the floor, checking h nearly empty refrigerator, stretched out on his Goodwill couch, watching TV. Finally, inspiration. Henry rushes to his desk and taps o a sentence or two on his computer, feeling proud for his accomplishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I graduated from the University of Illinois. English major. Taught high school for a couple years, but hated it. Moved out here to be a writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Henry's voice over continues, we see him in uniform wi pizza in hand at the front door of a house. Rings doorbel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work two jobs. Delivering pizzas and cleaning carpets. Good jobs for a writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry cleaning the carpets as the heavily-tattooed MOTORC DUDE points to a dirty spot: Over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You meet lots of interesting people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry points to the letters on the wall. C.U. picks up on phrases like "We regret to inform you," or "Sorry, but th story isn't right for us," or "The Baxter Agency currentl isn't accepting new clients."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have two unpublished novels. Working on my third, Pizza to Go. These are my rejection letters. Rejected by agents. Rejected by publishers. When you think about it, it's pretty amazing how many ways people can reject you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry, John, Alan, Colette, Hannah, and William sit aroun the table. Impressive buffet of cold cuts, cheeses, and shrimp has been set out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our writing group meets every Tuesday night. Mostly at Alan and Colette's. Sometimes we rotate. John helps himself to some shrimp.   Then helps himself t some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love coming to the group. Everyone always has such constructive feedback. It's like we're all in this together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really like the way Yuri is developing, Colette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you ask John K. Butzin... Can't help looking at the camera. Making sure it's on him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still going to have to explain why this Natasha dame goes AWOL on her husband. Still kinda iffy to me. Another glance at the camera: Did you get that? ALAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was bothered by that, too. Why would Natasha betray a reliable, dependable husband for a washed-up young punk? All eyes on Colette.    She shifts in her chair.   Uncomf

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.   Well...um...um... An uneasy silence. Colette is blocked--nowhere to go creatively. Her face tightens up. Bites her lip. COLETTE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God. I've been rewriting and rewriting and rewriting and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poodles.     It's OK. COLETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's not OK. I still can't explain Natasha's motive. What's the use? I'm not a writer. William to the rescue. WILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa. Whoa. Time out. The dude's good in bed. Trust me, that's all the motive she needs. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger that. Torpedo Chapter Three. Blow it up. Get the focus back on this broad--Natasha. HENRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Yes. I was thinking the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it clear that Natasha wants to be closer... Colette makes notes furiously, nodding in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Writing can be such a solitary existence, so it's good to have this outlet where you can meet other writers and exchange ideas. Here it really is all for one and one for all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that evening.    Meeting is over. Alan, Colette, Hannah, Henry, William, and John are all standing up now. William stretches. John reaches for more shrimp. Friendly banter. Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who wants coffee? Everybody does.    William taps Henry on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lend me ten bucks? I'm having cash flow issues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, bro'. You're the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry sits at his desk, staring at the blank computer. Lo in thought. Emphasis on lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This new novel Pizza to Go is about Scott, a pizza delivery guy in LA. He comes across some interesting characters. I like what I have so far, but it's only a hundred pages and I'm stuck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry stands in front of the mirror in his apartment, wea the Pizza Starz hat and shirt. Ready for work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Haven't written a word in the last two weeks. Not one. Hannah teases me about having writer's block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASHBACK to the last group meeting. Focus on Hannah. Her smile. Her warmth. She listens and comments. Actively engaged in the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I keep thinking about her. She's all I think about. Really would like to ask her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah reaches for a pair of READING GLASSES and slips th on. Talks to someone O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think? On or off? Do they make me look smarter? I need a new pair. She takes the glasses off. Puts them back on. Off again. Debating. Hannah prepares herself with a series of quick breaths and waves her hands in the air. Then she stares directly into the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm originally from Prescott, Arizona. Followed my mom out here about four years ago. That's her back there. Camera picks up a wisp of a WOMAN (over 50)in the backgro waving, with an equally pleasant smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My parents are divorced. Not her fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William favors jeans and faded tweed jacket. Sits in the corner of a Valley restaurant, nursing a cup of coffee an talks to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to know about me? I'm 27. Single. A virgin. He flashes that wicked, seductive smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just kidding. I'm actually 28. Hometown is Modesto, California, A sprawling junk heap of a town without a soul. Why did I come to LA? Um, because I knew you were here and that you'd loan me a hundred bucks if I needed it. Right? WAITRESS #1 refills his coffee cup. Her reward is that sm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, babe. She walks away.   William admires the view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already got her number. Maybe I'll text her. Maybe I won't. Eyes back towards the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So 'bout that hundred bucks? What d'ya think? A hint of desperation in his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. What about fifty? C'mon, bro'. Support the arts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah continues talking to the camera.   Maureen still i background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always had this knack for telling stories. Ever since I was a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a natural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moved here. Took a couple writing classes. Decided to go for it. 24/7. Total dedication to my craft. The writing always comes first. My latest effort is called Sleeping on the Moon. It's about rejection. And pain. Not really about the moon itself. More of a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She searches for the word that escapes her. Maureen to th rescue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Metaphor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William continues talking to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. LA? I'm here because of Bukowski. Charles Bukowski. Greatest writer ever. Period. INSERT ARCHIVAL PHOTOS of Charles Bukowski.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LA is his town, man. If I'm gonna be a writer, then I have to walk in Bukowski's shoes. Experience and capture the plight of the working class. He waves to WAITRESS #1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like the people in the group. But they can't write worth shit. But, man, Hannah is something. She's the only reason I keep going. Not because I'm learning anything. Hell, no. I just think she's hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah leans forward towards the camera, as if to hear be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My favorite writer? Favorite writer. Favorite writer... Hannah goes blank. The smile disappears as her face goes into noticeable contortions. This is worse than Final Jeopardy. She turns quiet, squirming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Favorite. Wow. Hard to say. I've studied Composition more than actual Literature. Gee. I know Maureen enjoys Jane...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Searching for a last name, Hannah looks back to Maureen f help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Austen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the one. I hear she's good. But my favorite writer? Let me think about that a bit, OK? Short beat. Hannah lowers her voice, almost a loud confessional whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't go to college.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John is holding court at his mobile home, showcasing the finest in furniture from Sears. John stuffs his home with various MILITARY ARTIFACTS--photos, equipment, books. He' got it all. John talks to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything John K. Butzin knows about writing comes down to two simple words: Tom Clancy. Yes, sir. Tom Clancy. The man's a genius. Does his research. All those nitty-gritty technical details. Now that's writing! John K. Butzin has one agent very interested in Roaring Lion. And a publisher up in Oxnard is looking at it as we speak. Plus a certain cousin's best friend has a neighbor who has an in with Clint Eastwood, so Hollywood might be calling soon. Don't know how the other members of the writing group will handle all this success by one person. They better not be pussies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan and Colette remain on the couch. Talking to the came All smiles. Much more comfortable with the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm an optometrist in Glendale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I write full-time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our last name's Mooney. You could call us Mooneys. We get that joke all the time. The couple giggle at the joke. Forced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which writer do I admire? Hmmm. How about John Grisham? Look at all that money he's made! Just teasing, John. We know you deserved every dime, but, hey, John, could you spread it around a bit, pal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan likes to tease. She gives her husband an affectionate squeeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette, here, is the real writer. I'm more of an idea guy. I come up with great ideas, but don't always follow through. I'll show you. He picks up his mini-digital Olympus RECORDER off the cof table. Thinks for a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To recorder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Idea for romantic novel. Alan catches himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Make that, idea for romantic ebook. He winks at the camera--showing he's hip to the jargon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possible movie option, too: Frovers. They couldn't be friends. They couldn't be lovers. So they became Frovers. Satisfied, Alan turns off the recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette opens the sliding glass door and steps out into a beautiful garden area. Quiet and private. Camera follows her over to a solitary BENCH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where I come for inspiration. I believe a writer must have quiet and solitude. I'll meditate. Write in my journal. Set out my creative path for the day. This is my Walden Pond. Colette sits down on the bench. Takes in the environment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Favorite author? I'd have to say Joan Didion. Her writing sends shivers down my spine. Though Joyce Carol Oates has been known to bring me to actual orgasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette sits on her bench, reading a BOOK. C.U. reveals that it is a novel by Joyce Carol Oates. Colette appears be getting into the story just a bit too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POOL GUY and GARDENER hear Colette's sensual cries drifti over the hedge. What the hell? They exchange puzzled look

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to the present. Camera picks up a FRAMED PHOTO OF OP from a corner of the bench. Holds it up for camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, this? I keep Oprah out here for luck. She's done so much to help writers. I know I'm going to be on her television show one day. I just know it. Colette can already see the moment in her mind. Short bea Then she looks off-camera--listening to someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Oprah doesn't have a TV show anymore? Really? Since when? Short beat as she hears the answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Short beat as she tries to cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew that. I did. I-I knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry stands in front of his mirror. Checks his appearanc Again. Talks to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight's the night. I'm going to ask Hannah out. Henry becomes lost in thought.   Regroups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time. I like her. She likes me-- I think. I've got to take action. Still stuck on Page 100. So I'm asking Hannah out on a date tonight. It'll be great. And I'll put this writer's block behind me. Checks his appearance one last time in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wish me luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan sits in his favorite chair, talking directly to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the group leader. After all, getting together was my idea. They're all my patients. That's how we met. First one published gets a free eye exam. Alan cackles a bit too hard at that joke.    He listens t question being asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did I form the group? To help Colette. Oh, I certainly enjoy the creative process, but Colette? Writing is her dream. I'd do anything for her because...because she's my dream. So there you have it. Alan reaches for his tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possible names for future characters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony Gilmore. No, wait. Make that Anthony T. Gilmore. Much better. Slate McCoy. Fletcher Peck. Fiona Foxx. And...a man known simply as Banjo. Satisfied, Alan turns off the recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Place is empty. Alan, Colette, William, John, and Henry gather around the center table. The WRITERS AT WORK poster is propped up against a nearby empty chair. Hard not to notice the EMPTY CHAIR at the ta Hannah is missing. Waitress #1 pours coffee all around. Henry fidgets in his chair, focused on the empty chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To William)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come we never chow down at your place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my place. Close to the working people. John rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Hannah? Anyone know? Nobody responds. Alan checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time to get started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't we wait for Hannah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go, people. I'm ready to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William's right. We'll start. She'll show up. William starts passing out pages. Henry eyes the empty ch Colette looks over William's pages. There are only three. She has a puzzled look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William, aren't these the same pages you read last time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope, they're different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're different. I changed a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Writing is rewriting, Colette. Bukowski said, "Write five words. Rewrite seven."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Dorothy Parker said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One word?    Jesus H. Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my creative vision, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Jumping in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which we are here to support. This is William's decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me just read. See if you can pick out the word. Tell me if it's better, or worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Muttering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One goddamn word. Henry continues staring at the empty chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The evening meeting is winding to an end. John stands up stretch. Alan slides papers into his leather satchel. HANNAH'S CHAIR remains empty. Henry remains concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HENRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder what happened to Hannah. ALAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not like her to miss. The mystery is quickly solved. Front door opens. In rushe Hannah, dashing directly towards the others, looking harr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry. I'm so sorry for missing the meeting. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? Your car break down? ALAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You oversleep? COLETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maureen. Is Maureen OK? WILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People. C'mon. Look at her. That glow. Hannah met a guy. She got laid. Hannah gives William a playful smack on the back. HANNAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, I did meet a guy. WILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told ya. HANNAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name's Brian. Check out Henry. He looks absolutely horrified. No! Hannah takes a deep breath and flashes a smile the size o the Grand Canyon. HANNAH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my new agent! She remembers the camera. HANNAH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Directly to camera) An agent. I've got an agent! Surprise and silence. The writers look at each other and then back at Hannah. Not quite sure how to react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stunned as Hannah turns her attention back to the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That writing class I took? Well, for the final project, I turned in the first chapter of Sleeping on the Moon. I guess the teacher liked it. Then he gave it to his friend who's an agent. Brian. He called. Had to see me right away. Brian wants to sign me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet Brian wants more than that. Playful smack from Colette to William on the shoulder: Be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's so great, Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I salute you, young lady. And he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   Fantastic. Fanntasstic. Henry takes it all in quietly, unable to speak. Alan bounces up and gives Hannah a big hug as the others immediately start peppering her with questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette, Alan, John, William and Henry encircle a beaming Hannah as Waitress #1 snaps their PHOTO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan pops the drugstore CHAMPAGNE and pours into the chea plastic cups, as Colette passes them around to Hannah, He John, and William.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Raising cup)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Hannah! Everyone clinks their cups together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. But I just want to remind everyone that we're all in this together. I couldn't have come this far without the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All for one . . . . But our camera picks up on the individual writers and something is amiss. Everything seems a beat off. People appear happy, but a little subdued. The joy seems a bit t forced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm merely the first one to get signed. But we're all going to have an agent soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, as a matter of fact, there's an agent in Santa Monica very interested in John K. Butzin. He's reading the manuscript as we speak. The others let John's remark pass without comment.   Will taps Henry on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Lower voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, can you lend me ten bucks? Henry is still a bit dazed by this unexpected turn of eve

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, bro'. You're the best. Henry's eyes can't leave Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door to the restaurant swings open and the writ group members tumble out into the evening. Alan carries h WRITERS AT WORK sign. William makes a move towards Hannah, but the the ever- protective Henry grabs her gently by her elbow, cutting William off. They start walking in one direction. William and John head out in the other. Meanwhile, Alan and Colet wave enthusiastically to Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations again, Hannah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes.   Way to go, Hannah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Calling back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you! 'Night. Alan and Colette continue to smile and wave until Hannah out of ear shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Hannah's got an agent. Short beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must have slept with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course she did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry and Hannah arrive at her car. She unlocks the front door of her clunker-of-a-Ford as Henry waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so proud of you, Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your turn will come, Henry. You're a better writer than I am. So much better. You went to college. Hannah looks directly into the camera, pointing to Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a great writer. Henry Obert. I knew him when. Henry, clearly embarrassed, puts his hand up to block the camera. Tries to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen. Maybe some afternoon we could go for a drive. There are some special places I'd like to show you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. I can't believe I've lived out here four years and haven't seen -- She stops in mid-sentence.   A light goes on in her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four years. It's been four years since I moved here. And now I have an agent. It's the number four again. My lucky number. I should have known this was going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no one more deserving. Hannah rewards Henry's praise with a peck on the lips. a warm hug. Hannah steps in her car, starts it up and rolls down the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to dedicate my novel to you. A final wave and Henry watches as she disappears into the night. He sighs.

dialogues.speaker: SHOTS
dialogues.text: A series of shots featuring the writers writing--or, at l trying: Alan pauses between eye appointments to record an idea. William continues scribbling at the restaurant, this time eyeing WAITRESS #2. Hannah, sitting cross-legged on her bed, types away on he laptop computer. Colette sits on her private bench, seeking inspiration. John sits at his keyboard. Vintage black-and-white war mo plays on the TV. John appears more interested in the movi Henry stares at his laptop. The screen is blank. Henry surrenders yet again and flips off the computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry, sitting in his studio apartment, wears his pizza delivery outfit. Ready for work. Talks to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm happy for Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, her getting an agent sort of ruins my plans, doesn't it? I mean, Hannah has an agent. I don't. That won't work for dating. I can't ask her out until I get an agent. Henry gestures at a PHOTOGRAPH taped to the wall among hi rejection letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Richard Benedict. He's written seven novels. Fantastic writer. INSERT ARCHIVAL PHOTOS of Richard Benedict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fitzgerald of his generation. Richard Benedict made me want to be a writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette dressed in a leotard, practices basic yoga on a m in her living room. Chanting. Overly dramatic, as always. Takes a break and talks to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My novel is called Nyet, Not Yet. It's about a Russian woman who comes to this country in search of love. It was inspired by a story I heard from one of my massage clients, Yuri. Yes, it's true--I used to do massage. In fact, that's how I met Alan, though I certainly didn't give him the kind of massage he really wanted. At least not the first time. Colette allows herself a slight smile at the memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will get an agent. It comes down to this: if Hannah can get an agent, I can get an agent. After all, I am a graduate of Mills College.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plopped down in her rocking chair, Hannah talks to someon O.S. Maureen goes about her day in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I thought of my favorite author yet? No. Not yet. There are so many, you know? The deep breaths and waving of hands begin again. Here co that smile as she looks directly into the camera. HANNAH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. I am somewhat superstitious. Yes. Guilty. I'm drawn to the number 4. I was born at exactly 4:04 p.m. on April 4th. 4-4-4-4. That wasn't an accident. No way. She's dead serious. HANNAH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certain things I've learned to avoid. Black cats. Cracked mirrors. Oh. And the number 13 especially. I hate the number 13. Hate it. Conversation interrupted by RINGING DOORBELL. Hannah frow at the interruption as Maureen scurries to the door and o it, revealing Colette hiding behind a HUGE GIFT BASKET. S breezes in. Takes over. Over the top. COLETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi...Hi...Hello everyone. I was just in the neighborhood and-- Colette freezes when she notices the camera. COLETTE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Hannah. I'm so sorry. I didn't know they'd be here-- Yeah, right. Hannah springs up. Follows Colette as she se the basket down for all to admire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette.    What a lovely surprise! Hugs all around between Hannah and Maureen and Colette. Hannah looks blown away by the gift basket. HANNAH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My, what's this? COLETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. It's nothing. I just had to say "Congratulations" to my new favorite author.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah is truly touched.    Maureen notices a CARD attach the basket. MAUREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reading) "For Poodles...Now may we have sex again? Love, Alan." What? Embarrassed, Colette snatches the card from Maureen Hannah is more focused on the gift. Doesn't really hear. HANNAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So sweet of you, Colette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pleasure.     Say, Hannah...about your agent? Hannah looks over at Colette: What? COLETTE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he--Is he taking on new clients?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee.   I don't really know. Colette blurts out without thinking. COLETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think you could ask? Awkward situation for Hannah.      How best to respond?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so.     Maybe. COLETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if he is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's talk about this at group meeting, OK? COLETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Of course. Of course. Absolutely. Long beat. Conversation over. The three women wait for on another to speak. Colette checks her watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... A hug for both Maureen and Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to go. Talk soon. By the way, everything in the basket--gluten free! A final wave to the camera and Colette disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette Mooney. My, that woman is something else. A light goes off in Hannah's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To herself; counting on her fingers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette Mooney. C-o-l-e-t-t-e M-o-o- n-e... She can't finish the count. The ugly truth is staring her the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 letters.    Oh, dear... Hannah and Maureen exchange concerned looks.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ALAN'S OFFICE DAY
dialogues.text: Hannah and Henry sit together in the reception area. Alan breezes in, ever-smiling, greeting both enthusiastically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rows of EYE GLASSES on display as Alan guides Hannah over the fitting table. Henry tags along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for seeing me today, Alan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problemo. Let's get you some new eye wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something that makes me look smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're already smart, Hannah. Hannah gives Henry's hand a playful squeeze: Thank you. Alan and Hannah sit down opposite from each other. Henry pulls up a chair to the side. Alan selects a pair. Puts t on Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about... Hannah shrugs her blase reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmmmmm. Alan removes the brown-colored frames.   Studies them for second. Then -- inspiration arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.   One sec. He reaches inside his coat pocket for his RECORDER. Speak into it. ALAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Name for character. Alexander Brown. Wears brown-colored glasses. HANNAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course he would. Henry nods, agreeing. Satisfied, Alan puts the recorder away and reaches for another pair of glasses. ALAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know this great idea for a novel hit me this morning. It's called Unleashed. Alan tries the second pair on Hannah. She checks herself the mirror. Then she shows Henry. They both shake their h No. It is a funny moment between friends. They laugh as A reaches for pair #3. ALAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about a dog who becomes human for 24 hours in order to rescue his kidnapped owner. I love this idea, Hannah. HANNAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be a winner. Alan puts the third pair of glasses on Hannah. She checks herself in the mirror, finally liking what she sees. She looks over towards Henry. HANNAH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think? Poor Henry. She does look good. He's falling even harder her by the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look great, Hannah. Hannah can't decide. She studies herself in the mirror as Henry studies her. Henry reaches for his ANDROID and snap a photo of her. Alan brings them back to real time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Question: You think your agent might be interested in this idea? Does he have a dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Evading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I don't know--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about a cat? It could be a cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um. Sure.   Probably could be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about mentioning it to your agent, OK? Unleashed. Dog -- or cat -- becomes human. Alan beams with pride at his imagination on display. Hann fidgets. Avoids Alan. Henry jumps in to save the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll help you develop the idea, Alan. Alan looks pleased. Hannah looks grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TWO MIDDLE-AGED WOMEN (CUSTOMER #1 AND CUSTOMER #2) s across from each other in the nearly-deserted restaurant. Body language suggests an intense, passionate, personal c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A writer has to hear everything. On the streets. In the restaurants. But something's amiss. Customer #1 stops abruptly, glanci at the table next to them: William has suddenly materiali Sitting with a cup of coffee and a legal pad, scribbling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dialogue has to be real so I'm everywhere. Standing behind you at the checkout stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Customer #1 resumes conversation, but looks sharply back William. His head is tilted towards them. Listening. WILLIAM (V.O.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peeing next to you at the urinal. I watch. I listen. Customer #1 says something to Customer #2. Looks back at William. His head is still cocked as he makes notes. WILLIAM (V.O.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Writing down scraps of conversation. Customer #1 grows more agitated. Customer #2 tries to cal her down. Finally, Customer #1 shoots up and marches over to William, her finger jabbing in the air towards the notebook. William shrugs, playing dumb. WILLIAM (V.O.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. I eavesdrop. Customer #1 reaches down and grabs the notebook from Will He tries to stop her, but too late. WILLIAM (V.O.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How else do you accurately capture the misery of the human condition? She reads the page and shows it to Cutomer #2 who reads t notes and is equally shocked. WILLIAM (V.O.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Bukowski says "An intellectual says a simple thing in a hard way." The two women start yelling at William. He keeps shaking head. Customer #1 tears the page into shreds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "An artist says a hard thing in a simple way." Waitress #2 comes over. The women talk to her and she sta yelling at William. Customer #1 poking her finger in his chest. Escalates to a push. The COOK comes out and starts yelling at William. WILLIAM (V.O.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta love it. That's me. Simple. Real. Surrounded by yelling people, William breaks through the circle and moves towards the door. The BUS BOY yells, too

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powerful.   An artist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John grins for the camera. The reason why sits next to hi in the matching LAWN CHAIRS. The WOMAN is clearly younger than John. Plainly dressed i faded sweat shirt. Little makeup. Nervous in front of the camera, but she looks more at us than she does at John. H can't keep his eyes off her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meet someone very s-p-e-c-i-e-l. Here with us today all the way from... Coaxing Sigrid to finish the thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Germany.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! That accent! Found her    working at the hardware store. Went   in for a drill bit. Came out with a    prime candidate for Mrs. John K.    Butzin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch Sigrid work. Hard. Uber hard. Stocking shelves. Run cash register. Consulting HER BOSS -- an older man. Assisting customers. Moving boxes. Always wearing a red employee vest. She does speak with a thick accent. Sincer if naive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Starts speaking German. Stops. In English)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apologies. American only. I come from Dusseldorf, yes? Came to this great country 90 years ago -- no, 90 days ago. Apologies. Took job in store as cleaning lady. Promoted to cashier. Now assistant, assistant manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sigrid stands next to a wall display. Everything and anyt to do with the U.S. is hanging on this wall: Magazine cov of Obama. A U.S. flag. Burger King logo. Photo of Jay Len

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: N.Y. Yankees pennant. Whatever comes to mind for the U.S. seems to be taped, tacked, glued or whatever to that wall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This my 'Wall of America' tribute, yes? To my new country. And in the center, of course, the three men I admire most in America. First we see the FRAMED PHOTO of a certain business mogul

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herr Trump.    Very rich. Very famous. Very sexy. Then we move on to the second PHOTO of a certain TV celeb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herr Simon Cowell. Very rich. Very famous. Very sexy. Move on to the third PHOTO.     Hey, we know this person:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja. My special guy. Herr Bootzin. About to become very rich. Very famous. Already very sexy. (Beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then maybe Sigrid Hagenguth becomes Mrs. John K. Bootzin, ja?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette sits. Focused on the WHITE ENVELOPE in one hand. Alan sits next to her, squeezing her other hand. Photo of Oprah on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know this is a rejection letter. I can't open this. I can't be rejected today. I take rejection so personally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet it's good news. She opens the envelope. Peeks inside. No letter. Just the SMALLEST POST-IT NOTE flutters out on to the ground. Cole picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Sorry. Not interested." I knew it. How can such a big rejection come from such a small piece of paper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette folds the Post-It Note in half--and then in quart Holding it in her hand, she begins to chant. Alan holds o to her hand and pats her on the back. Good husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah and Maureen watch with interest and obvious appreciation as Henry, dutifully wearing his uniform, cle their living room carpet. Open PIZZA STARZ ГЌBOX on the breakfast bar. Looks like H has brought dinner, as well. Hannah's iPhone goes off. As courtesy, Henry stops the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Yes. Oh, hi, Brian. (LISTENING) Really? (LISTENING) Oh my god! Oh my god! Oh my god! Hannah starts jumping up and down like a little girl whil Maureen and Henry look on in bewildered anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sold my novel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Nodding excitedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian sold Sleeping on the Moon! Now Maureen starts jumping up and down. Henry can't hide surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god!   Oh my god!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On telephone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Brian. I will. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. I will. Promise. Thank you! Hannah turns off her iPhone. Mother and daughter can't believe the news. Jumping up and down. Warm embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In turn, they both embrace Henry, who also shares the genuine, sincere moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did it, Hannah!   You did it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so proud of you, dear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Another embrace between mother and daughter.   This could on all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to tell the group! The smile disappears from Hannah's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group. Oh, dear. The group. No, no, I can't tell them about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. She looks to Maureen for support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will seem like I'm bragging or something. I mean I'm the one with an agent. Now this. It could be too much, too soon, don't you think? Henry understands.   He wants to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose I tell them? They could hear the news from me. Hannah lights up at the suggestion. She goes to Henry and gives him a tight hug. So very tight. Blesses him with an friendly peck on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, my friend. I can always depend on you, can't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John talks to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great for Hannah, her little book deal, and all. But John K. Butzin has some news to announce, as well. John holds up a BROCHURE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just inked a deal with U R the Publisher, a reputable company based in New Delhi. They publish 5000 titles internationally every year. Paying 'em two hundred dollars and they're going to format and publish my novel Roaring Lion. I've waited for this moment forever. Finally, a Butzin is going to be a published author. A voice drifts in from another room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yoo-hoo. Mr. Published-Author-to-Be. Sigrid would like you to come in for personal, private autograph. Please. Please. John gulps. Then he remembers the camera.    Makes a "cut motion with his finger across the neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry's turn to host the group meeting. Alan, William, Colette, and John share the lumpy couch and the folding m chairs. Open PIZZA STARZ BOXES in the background. Everyone is enjoying a single slice of pizza off a paper plate--except for John, who is inhaling two pieces at onc The mood is somber. Quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah's just lucky. That's all. John tries to agree, but his mouth is too stuffed with pi Cheap FLOWERS from Ralph's and BALLOONS in full display o the coffee table. Henry stands--listening--by the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here she comes! Henry opens the door. Hannah floats in. The serious expressions suddenly, magically, turn to broa smiles. Henry is the first to offer a hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan, William, Colette, John give her a standing ovation. Hannah notices the balloons and flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhhhhh.    For me? You shouldn't have. WILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Way to go, Ms. Published Author! Everyone gets a hug from Hannah. William gives Hannah an extra long hug. ALAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all jealous, Hannah. Just teasing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   Seriously. We're all jealous. Nervous laughter around the room. HANNAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all making too much of a spectacle here. HENRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When will your book come out, Hannah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A year.    Takes about a year. WILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how much did you get? ALAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ask her that. WILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shrugging) Why not? How much did you get? HANNAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did OK. Leave it at that. What's important is that I owe this success to all of you. I would be lost without this writing group. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Louder than normal) I don't know if anyone heard. All eyes turn to John, still inhaling pizza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But U.R. the Publisher has agreed to publish Roaring Lion by John K. Butzin. Puzzled looks are the reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: U.R. the Publisher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They self-publish. E-books. Print on Demand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Obert. But I'll have my book in two weeks. None of this B.S. waiting around. John K. Butzin will be a published author. And be published first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Ever-diplomatic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, John. Congratulations. She leans over and gives him the briefest of hugs. There other congratulatory murmurs coming from the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My, two published authors in the group. The rest of us are going to have to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The meeting gets down to business. Alan, Colette, Henry, William and Hannah, wearing her new glasses, listen as Jo reads from Roaring Lion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunner stared out over the bleak horizon, seeing one dead Viet Cong after another lay scattered on the bloody hillside. He had won this time, but Gunner knew Charlie would be back in the morning. By god, he would be ready. So would his M60 General Purpose Machine Gun and Mark 2 Fragmentation/Hand Rifle Grenade. John finishes and sits back in his chair, quite pleased w himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, John. Nicely done. Let's get some feedback. Henry, as always, has been making notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.   In terms of the characters--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Jumping in) --Hold on, Obert. I wanna hear from her. John points towards Hannah. ALAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll hear from everybody. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear from everybody. She has a book coming out. John K. Butzin has a book coming out. I want to hear from Hannah, author to author. WILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, screw you. ALAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is really going against the spirit of the group, John. Everyone's opinion is valid. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hers is more valid. What'd you think, Hannah? Tell me. Hannah struggles to speak. Clearly uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: I-I . . .
dialogues.text: The words freeze in her mouth. Awkward silence. Finally. WILLIAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Standing up) Going outside for a smoke. William thunders away from the group. Colette watches him go. COLETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go talk to him. Colette follows, calling after William.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take a fifteen minute break, shall we? Embarrassed, Hannah excuses herself. Henry trails along a her, leaving a muttering John and calm Alan alone. Alan reaches for his recorder. Talks into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh, idea for Michael Crichton-type novel. Members of Antarctic research station attacked by mutant penguins. Satisfied, Alan turns off the recorder while John reaches for more pizza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette is back on her bench. Standing behind her is a mysterious MAN (Over 40) who favors black clothes and dar shades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to meet someone special. This is my spiritual adviser. Doctor Xiroman has taken a vow of silence for one full year to protest climate change. What an amazing man. Dr. Xiroman is going to cleanse the air of all this rejection. Camera goes to Dr. Xiroman. Somber, expressionless. Does even have a pulse? Dr. Xiroman walks over to small fire pit and meditates as places his hands over the rising flames. Colette begins a New Age chant for added support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE YOUNG MEN in the corner booth. Jeans and baseball c Very animated conversation. Loud, punctuated by laughter. They think they're the only people in the joint. The WAIT EUDORA (20's)--with the purple streaks in her hair and matching purple glasses, refills their cups. William sits alone at the counter, impossible to hide his disdain. He talks to the camera with the three men in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See those jokers back there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They "write" for TV. Town's full of them. Creative vultures. Anything for a paycheck. Fade in. Fade out. C.S.I. 24. Who Wants to Suck My -- William scoffs as the disdain drips from his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme a break. Television. Telecrap. They've sold their souls to the devil. For what? A house in Malibu? A tennis court? William glances over his shoulder, shaking his head in disgust. Another table catches his eye. TWO ATTRACTIVE WO engage in friendly banter over coffee. William stares the down, making friendly eye contact. The woman facing him returns eye contact. She smiles.   W smiles, watching them as he continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That will never be me. I will never compromise my vision for financial gain. I'd rather borrow money from friends than sell out for a quick dollar. The two women stand up. William is stoked. This is too ea But the women instead go to the three TV writers. Immedia invited to sit down with them. William can't believe it.   What the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...Gatsby had an extraordinary gift for hope, a romantic readiness...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry reads from The Great Gatsby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...such as I have never found in any other person and which it is not likely I shall ever find again..." Henry is always moved whenever he reads Fitzgerald.   Put down the book, he talks to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, the year before he died, F.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott Fitzgerald made a grand total of $13.13 in royalties from his writing. I guess Hannah's right about 13 being unlucky. A question is asked O.S. Henry listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Sure. I know that. Gatsby does end tragically. But that's fiction. Hannah...She's real. Our story will have a happy ending. Pause.   Henry rethinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.   Maybe a happy ending. His confidence flies out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope. Hope we have a happy ending. Fingers crossed. 52   INT. ALAN & COLETTE'S HOUSE -- LIVING ROOM - DAY Alan and Colette hold court on their living room couch, talking to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's been one rule in this house. Whatever Colette wants, Colette gets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Alan. They look at each other adoringly.   Real or fake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wants a Mercedes? No problem. Credit cards? How many? Her own business? Done. An agent? Colette eats it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call it karma or serendipity or kismet. Whatever. But it just so happens that very well-known literary agent David Keller--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Very well-known. He's so known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. Well, guess who is coming in tomorrow to see Dr. Alan Mooney for an eye examination and new glasses? Colette starts squealing in anticipation. Alan nods with confidence and flashes a "thumbs up."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Poodles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love you more, Poodles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The casually dressed MAN (40's) sits in the waiting area Alan Mooney, spending time on his iPhone, conducting busi as he waits.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTION
dialogues.text: He doesn't have to wait long. Alan personally comes out into the waiting area to fetch him. Big grin. Hand extend

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Alan Mooney. David, caught off guard by the doctor's sudden appearance winds up his phone conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me call you back. David stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Keller. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Big fan. Big fan. David can't help but notice the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that. They're doing a little documentary about my writing group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just act natural. Lowering his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was supposed to be a reality series.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standard examination room. Alan guides David into the cha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Let's start out with a basic eye examination. Alan flips a couple SWITCHES. Eye reading CHART appears o the wall. Alan turns off the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, David. See if you can read that first line for me, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, David. Would you like to try for what's behind Door Number Three? Try this one, please. Alan brings up a different line on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20/25. Looking good, David. But anyone can identify simple letters and numbers. Let's see how you do reading a more challenging text. Alan brings up a different page. Several paragraphs on a printed page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Read me the first paragraph, please. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reading; monotone) Natasha, the Russian peasant, dressed oh-so-slowly, consumed totally, completely, absolutely, by endless thoughts of Yuri. ALAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Very nice. Very nice. Now the next paragraph, please. David looks rather puzzled, but complies. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reading; monotone) "I never, ever thought I could feel this way," Natasha said excitedly. "Nor could I," Yuri said happily, his body dripping with enormous beads of sweat. ALAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man. Wow. Gee. Isn't that great writing? My wife Colette wrote that. The patients just love reading her stuff. It's from her new novel, Nyet, Not Yet. A loud KNOCK on the examination room door. David is saved the bell. ALAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My, I wonder who that could be. He walks over to the door, opens it and feigns surprise t see Colette. She moves right in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, honey.   So sorry to intrude. ALAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette? Gee, this is an incredible coincidence. We were just talking about you. And here you are! Colette is locked like a laser beam on David Keller. COLETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Gushing) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, where are my manners? Colette, this is David Keller. David, this is my wife, Colette Mooney. The writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleasure to meet you, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, Colette wrote this beautiful prose you've been reading, David. Honey, I can't believe this coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I was just dropping off--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Overlapping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, of course. Thanks for bringing it by. Say, honey, David's been reading that first page of yours. You don't happen to have any more of that opening chapter, do you? Colette thinks for a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, I think I do. I think I do. Colette searches her large PURSE and produces a manila fo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, how about that? Colette hands the manila folder to David, who accepts it reluctantly. He's been had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette sits in the chair, Alan stands behind her, massag her shoulders. Both share that smirk of satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That went very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, Poodles.    Very.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though David Keller did seem in a hurry to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sooner he can begin reading. Colette buys that.    Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet he calls tomorrow with an offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet he calls tonight. Alan's left hand starts to slide down towards Colette's c She doesn't notice--her mind is elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID takes Colette's pages and tosses them in city TRASH CAN, muttering to himself as he walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Overlapping Alan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Overlapping Colette)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah sits cross-legged on her living room floor, wearin her new glasses, reading typed pages. Henry sits close to her. Not too close. Waiting. Hannah finishes. Impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry.     This is good.   So good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Hannah nods.   Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I've only got 100 pages.      Can't seem to move forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dying to know more about Scott and Christy. What great characters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sure wish I knew what was going to happen with them. Hannah gives Henry a friendly tap on the knee for encouragement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll figure it out, Henry. It'll pass. Focus on your writing. No distractions. The writing comes first. Henry lets it sink in.   Changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, um, remember I offered to drive you around and show you a couple special places?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The imposing house screams success.     Henry and Hannah Henry's parked car, taking it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who lives here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard Benedict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.   That writer you like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like? No. It's much more than that. Wow. He...He... Henry struggles to put it into words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Reading Richard Benedict...made me want to be a better writer. He's that good, Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't say I've read his stuff.     Nice house, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry and Hannah stand on the sidewalk in front of the No Hayworth home. Henry seems barely able to contain his excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we are. Hannah stares blankly at the house. HENRY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: North Hayworth Avenue. Hollywood, California. Hannah smiles politely, but it's clear she doesn't recogn the house. HENRY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big clue time. Sheila Graham. Still nothing registers with Hannah. HENRY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. Give up? Writer Sheila Graham lived here. Fitzgerald was her lover. This is where he died on December 21, 1940. Hannah lets it all sink in. HANNAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fitzgerald? He's the one who shot himself, right? HENRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Fitzgerald. F. Scott Fitzgerald. He wrote The Great Gatsby. The name doesn't register with Hannah. HENRY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reciting from heart) Gatsby believed in the green light, the orgiastic future that year by year recedes before us. It eluded us then, but that's-- HANNAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Interjecting) I've never read it. Henry can't hide his surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Hannah stops, cognizant of the ever-present camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To camera) Could you turn that off for a few minutes, please? HENRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know they can't. What's wrong? Hannah hesitates.   Counts to three. Lowers her voice. HANNAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never read The Great Gatsby. HENRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding. HANNAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry. I never went to college. I've heard of Hemingway. A little. Fitzgerald. Somewhere. But I don't have your education. Your smarts. I haven't read all these great novels. My stories come from my heart. Henry lets it all sink in.    Hannah looks at the house. HANNAH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about the book. HENRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gatsby is about social position and the American Dream and . . . Henry stops. Rethinks his explanation. HENRY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, it's quite simple. Boy meets girl. Boy loses girl. Boy moves heaven and earth to win the girl back. HANNAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's your favorite? Henry nods with his heart. HANNAH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how does it end? Does boy get the girl? Long beat. Then Henry reaches into the back seat of his c for his KNAPSACK. Puts it on his lap, unzips it. Pulls ou his personal copy of Gatsby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Take my copy. He hands the well-read book to Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you can find out for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John is on the telephone, clutching a copy of Roaring Lio He does not look happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On telephone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm still holding. Where are you again? New Dehli? Oh. John stares at his book, shaking his head. Waits for a fe seconds. Sigrid is in the background, doing light housekeeping, tr not to listen, but obviously can't avoid it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On telephone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butzin. John K. Butzin. Right. That's me. Roaring Lion. Yes. Well, I have a copy of my book you sent, but there must be some mistake...Well, you put a dog on the cover. Not a lion like we agreed. John holds the book up for the camera to catch the unmistakable dog barking on the front cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On telephone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plus the back cover is written in Chinese. Chinese...Yes, I know Chinese when I see it. One of those Chinese assault rifles almost cost me an eye at Hamburger Hill... John listens--trying to remain calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seem to be missing pages 1-0-7 to 1-1-2...Yes, I'm sure. And what in blazes is this Chapter Eight? Sigrid keeps cleaning.   Stoic expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On telephone)

dialogues.text: This Chapter Eight isn't mine. It's about hormone replacement for women. Do you think John K. Butzin would write that? Must be from another goddamn book. So what the hell you going to do about this? You, sir, are dealing with a decorated veteran-- a combat veteran--of the United States Army. John waits for an explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I'll hold. John looks again at his book in disbelief. Then he rememb the camera. Forces a faint smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minor details. That's all. All that truly matters is that John K. Butzin is finally a published author. But catch Sigrid's expression. She is quiet.     More tha little concerned at what she is hearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry and Hannah at a table, sharing coffee. Eudora the waitress swings by with a refill, hair purple as ever. Ha thumbs through her copy of Gatsby, looking interested. An pleased. Eudora notices the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great book.    Classic. Henry nods in agreement.   Eudora moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I needed this break. Thank you, Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that I'm starting to feel the pressure, you know? There is so much riding on this first book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly. Sleeping on the Moon will hit the bestseller list. You'll be the toast of the literary world. And I'll come over to Beverly Hills and deliver a pizza to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beverly Hills, ah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Definitely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parked on the street in front of Hannah's apartment. Henr and Hannah, this mutual admiration society, stand by the car. Hannah still has her copy of Gatsby. Short beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a dear, sweet friend you are. Hannah graces Henry with another hug. Another quick peck the lips. But wait--Henry wants more. He kisses her back. More than a peck. Too much more. Hannah, surprised, pulls back--her hand on his chest: Stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No distractions. The writing comes first, 'kay? Henry nods reluctantly: Understood. One last hug from Han before she heads for her front door, smiling back over he shoulder at Henry. Henry watches her leave, knowing that this was absolutely, positively, the best day of his life
